answers.answer: another tonometry test would be the conservative route.  that would certainly rule out raised intraocular pressure.BUT: if it were hard enough that you, an untrained layperson could feel the difference, you'd have other problems as well... like cloudy vision, severe red eye or pain.  you cant have mildly raised IOP and "feel it", and you cant have GREATLY raised IOP and *not* feel it.  if it was high enough to make it feel hard to the touch, you'd likely also be in excruciating pain.much more likely that you just kind of noticed that the human eye is rather firm to the touch (it is) and you feel pressure from sinuses at the same time...

Since I have dealth with Thyroid Eye Disease for 4yrs now, I think if anyone has any eye problems, they should always see an Opthamologist over an Optometrist, just to be safe!  Since you already had your eyes checked due to possible retina problems, did they by chance check the pressure in your eyes?
Sure, they checked the pressure in each eye during the examination for a new prescription. But that was in December.. I have had the dilation and retinal exam since then, but no pressure testing.

i cannot refrain on weighing in.  apologies in advance for the rant:southern gal: what you posted is a very common misconception among many patients...that optometrists are just for glasses and contacts and ophthalmologists are the ones to go to if there's anything wrong.  that was true...in 1950.every single state has optometry "diagnostics" laws which means that not only are the optometrists who are licensed in that state forced to show competency in the diagnosis and management of almost all known eye diseases, they are also LIABLE if they miss a diagnosis of eye disease, or fail to manage it correctly.  so trust me, no optometrist is going to "miss" some horrible eye disease.  4/5 of optometry school is dedicated to learning about eye disease, i'm not joking.  we get more "eye" training in number of hours than most ophthalmologists ever do, b/c they are wasting their time in med school learning about diverticulitis and doing cpr on gunshot victims in the ER. etc.  at one of my internships i knew way, way more about everything that was remotely eye related than the ophthalmologist residents who were there.it doesnt help that the AMA totally propagtes this widely held but incorrect position on the differences between OD's & MD's.but i'll tell you the difference in the year 2006:ophthalmologists are surgeons.  you should go to an ophthalmologist if you think you need surgery.  go to an optometrist for literally everything else.  you do not necessarily need an ophthalmologist if your "eyes are bad" or if you've had some old injury or if you have diabetes or thyroid problems or anything else.  in fact in general if you plan on actually SEEING better...most optometrists are much better refractionsts so your Rx ends up being closer anyway.these are all my opinions, of course.
